headline: CNN Special Reports
subHeadline: CNN Special Report: American Coup: The January 6th Investigation. Aired 11p-12a ET

utterances.speaker: RICHARD DONOGHUE, ACTING DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: And then in the afternoon we got that email which I had to sit and read more than once to make sure I understood what he was proposing.

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: What was he proposing?

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: He was proposing sending out a letter signed by the three of us, the acting Attorney General, myself and Jeff Clark, to Georgia, but also the other States, the other swing states as well, suggesting essentially, that they set aside, the electors assigned to support President Elect Biden and hold hearings and basically had the state legislatures pick a new slate of electors.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The letter claimed that the U.S. Department of Justice's investigations have, "identified significant concerns that may have impacted the outcome of the election in multiple states including the State of Georgia". Was that true?

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: While the letter was sent solely by Jeff Clark, it was written with the help of a new Justice Department employee named Ken Klukowski, who according to the committee was also working with John Eastman, the architect of the multi-step plan to overturn the election. The letter mirrored some of Eastman's unconstitutional theories.

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: Would have created chaos in the states, I think that would have been disastrous for our country and our constitution.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But wasn't that the point of it the letter to create that casts?

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: I think so. Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Disturbed by the letter, Donoghue immediately responded to Clark writing, "This would be a grave step for the department to take and it could have tremendous constitutional political and social ramifications for the country".

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: I had to make it clear to him that there was no world in which I and certainly the AG were going to sign a letter like that.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Rosen and Donohue met with Clark later that evening.

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: I do remember at the very end, saying to him, what you're proposing is nothing less than having the United States Justice Department meddle in the outcome of an American presidential election.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But again, Jeffrey Clark ignored the direction of Justice Department leadership. He continued to claim falsely that there was widespread election fraud; he pushed to send out the letter again. And on January 3, he told Rosen, President Trump had offered him the role of Attorney General and he had accepted.

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: That lead to a series of discussions and meetings that day, at this point had gone so far that we had to bring other leaders and explain to them so they were prepared in case it happened, but also to get their take on what they would do if that did happen.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And what did they say they would do?

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: They uniformly said they will resign.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: White House Call Logs obtained by the committee show that by 4.19 p.m. that day, the White House had already begun referring to Clark as the acting Attorney General. That evening, Rosen and Donohue went to the White House to argue against Trump installing Clark as Attorney General. The three hour meeting took place in the Oval Office and by all accounts, joined the long list of wild White House meetings.

utterances.speaker: JEFFREY ROSEN, FORMER ACTING ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: The president turned to me and he said, well, one thing we know is you Rosen; you aren't going to do anything. You don't even agree with the claims of election fraud. And this other guy, at least might do something.

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: It was basically Jeff Clark advocating for the leadership change and everyone else advocating against it. It was a very blunt, contentious conversation. Herschmann and I were on the same level of being sort of the street fighters of the meeting.

utterances.speaker: ERIC HERSCHMANN, FORMER WHITE HOUSE SENIOR ADVISOR
utterances.sentences: When he finished discussing what he planned on doing. I said, good luck and see -- things right and behold. Congratulations, you just admitted the first step or act you take as attorney general would be committing a felony and violating rule 60. You're clearly the right candidate for this job.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: White House Counsel Pat Cipollone was vehemently against the plan as well.

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: He referred to the letter that Jeff Clark had submitted as a murder suicide pact, that no one should have anything to do with it. I had basically made the point that the President Jeff Clark was not even qualified to be the Attorney General. He's promising you he's going to conduct these very complex nationwide investigations in record time. And this is coming from a guy who's never conducted a real investigation. Mr. Clark responded by saying that he's been involved in very significant environmental law briefing before various courts. And that reminded me that yes, in fact, you're primarily you're an environmental lawyer. How about you go back to your office, and we'll call you when there's an oil spill.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Donohue also informed President Trump that upon Clark's appointment, justice department leaders would resign on mass.STEVEN ENGEL, FORMER U.S. ASSISTANT ATTORNEY GENERAL: The President turned to me and said, Steve, you wouldn't leave, would you? I said, Mr. President, I've been with you through four attorneys general, including two acting's attorney general, but I couldn't be part of this.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Finally persuaded Trump decided against the idea. When Clark was subpoenaed by the January 6 committee earlier this year, he refused to answer questions pleading the fifth more than one 125 times.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Coming up inside the plot to pressure the vice president.J. MICHAEL LUTTIG, RETIRED U.S. FEDERAL JUDGE: He would have immediately plunged the country into a paralyzing constitutional crisis. (END VIDEOTAPE) (COMMERCIAL BREAK) (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: On December 14, 2020--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Unanimously cast 16 votes for Joseph R. Biden.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: When the electors in each state gathered.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: All 16 electors cast their ballots for Joseph R. Biden.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So did fraudulent electors in seven swing states that Biden had won such as Arizona.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Donald J. Trump of the State of Florida number of votes 11.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN MILLER, TRUMP CAMPAIGN SENIOR ADVISER
utterances.sentences: And ultimate slate of electors in the contested states is going to vote and we're going to send those results up to congress. TAPPER

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Who do you remember being involved in those early discussions around the Thanksgiving time regarding having alternate electors meet?

utterances.speaker: CASSIDY HUTCHINSON, FORMER AIDE TO MARK MEADOWS
utterances.sentences: Mr. Giuliani, several of Mr. Giuliani's associates Mr. Meadows.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: One of the biggest supporters of this outrageous attempt to subvert American democracy was law professor and Trump Attorney John Eastman.

utterances.speaker: JOHN EASTMAN, FORMER TRUMP ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: The entire executive branch just headed by one guy.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Fragile intellectual electors were just step one in Eastman's plan, which he outlined in these memos and justified with false claims of, "Illegal actions by state and local election officials". Step two in his plan would have to be executed by Vice President Mike Pence on January 6, while presiding over the opening and counting of electoral ballots.

utterances.speaker: SARA MURRAY, CNN POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: What you can do is you can say, due to these disputes in these seven states, we're going to send this back to the states and the states would then be able to help Donald Trump win the election.REP. LIZ CHENEY (R-WY): It was a lie. In fact, on December 19 2020, just four days before Dr. Eastman sent this memo, Dr. Eastman himself admitted in an email that the fake electors had no legal weight. Referring to the fake electors is, "Dead on arrival in Congress".

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Trump campaign aides and outside lawyers shared their concerns about the scheme and emails reported on by the New York Times, Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater. And did they think what they were doing was legal?

utterances.speaker: MAGGIE HABERMAN, SENIOR POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, NEW YORK TIMES
utterances.sentences: And one email lawyer working in Arizona literally describes them as "fake electors", and says, so what we would be doing is sending these fake electors he has taken quotes to go cast ballots. In another email, there was a discussion about fear from some officials; this would be seen as "Treasonous".

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What might have happened, had Pence trying to go through with this idea that he could reject electoral votes and send them back to the States Biden won such as Arizona, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, Georgia. LUTTIG

utterances.speaker: GREG JACOB, FORMER LEGAL COUNSEL TO PENCE
utterances.sentences: There's just no way that the framers of the constitution who divided power and authority who separated it out who had broken away from George III and declared him to be a tyrant, there was no way that they would have put in the hands of one person the authority to determine who was going to be President of the United States.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But President Trump now saw Vice President Pence as the man who could keep him in the White House for four more years.REP. PETE AGUILAR (D-CA): On December 23, President Trump re-tweeted a memo from an individual named Ivan Raiklin, entitled "Operation Pence Card" that called on the Vice President to refuse the Electoral College votes from certain states that had certified Joe Biden is the winner.

utterances.speaker: EVAN PEREZ, CNN SENIOR JUSTICE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: He had been pressuring him behind the scenes. So now, he's going public, he's trying to get public pressure on Mike Pence.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The January 6 committee's interviews with White House attorneys made it clear that Pat Cipollone, Eric Hirschman and many others were appalled.

utterances.speaker: JASON MILLER, FORMER TRUMP CAMPAIGN SENIOR ADVISOR
utterances.sentences: The way it was communicated to me it was that Pat Cipollone thought the idea was, was nutty. And to what point confronted Eastman basically with the same sentiment.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What were your prior interactions with Eastman?

utterances.speaker: HIRSCHMAN
utterances.sentences: He described for me what he thought the ambiguity was in the statute. And he was walking through it at that time. And I said to hold on a second, I want to understand what you're saying. You're saying that you believe the Vice President, acting as President of the Senate can be the sole decision maker as to under your theory, who becomes the next President of the United States? And you said yes. I said, are you out of your f-ing mind?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The Vice President decided he could not buy in to Eastman's theories.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Short, was it your impression that the Vice President had directly conveyed his position on these issues to the president?MARC SHORT, FORMER CHIEF OF STAFF TO V.P. MIKE PENCE: Many times.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And had been consistent in conveying his position to the president?

utterances.speaker: SHORT
utterances.sentences: Very consistent. COLLINSDONALD TRUMP, 45TH U.S. PRESIDENT: I hope that our great vice president, our great vice president comes through for us, he's a great guy. For us if he doesn't come through, I won't like it but as much.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: He said Judge, do you know John Eastman? And I said, yes. John was a clerk of mine about 20, 25 years ago. And he said, well, John's advising the President and the Vice President, that the Vice President does not have to accept the Electoral College votes as they have been cast. I said, well, Richard, you can tell the vice president that I said he has no such authority whatsoever.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Why did you take the Twitter?

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: Well, the next morning, Richard calls and he said, look, we have to get your voice out to the country immediately within the next hour or two.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Judge Luttig with the help of his son sent his first ever Twitter thread.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: My son sent me Twitter instructions on how to tweet a thread of individual tweets that are under 140 cares. I had no earthly idea what any of this was about. I just told my son and send it to me right now or I'll cut you out of the will.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: He read me some of that thread.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: The only responsibility and power of the vice president under the constitution is to faithfully count the Electoral College votes as they had been cast. The constitution does not empower the vice president to alter in any way the votes that had been cast, either by rejecting certain of them or otherwise.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That Twitter threads spread and garnered attention around the world. But with just one day before congress was set to certify Biden's Electoral College victory, Trump continued to apply maximum pressure. In this tweet, "The Vice President has the power to reject fraudulently chosen electors "and when they met at the White House, on January 5.

utterances.speaker: AGUILAR
utterances.sentences: In the book, "Peril" Journalist Bob Woodward and Robert Costa write that the president said, "If these people say you have the power, when you want to?" The vice president says, "I wouldn't want any one person to have that authority". The president says, no, no, no. You don't understand, Mike, you can't do this. I don't want to be your friend anymore if you don't do this. TAPPER

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't remember if he said you are a wimp, you'll be a wimp. Wimp is the word I remember.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's also been reported that the president said to the vice president that something to the effect that you don't have the courage to make a hard decision.GEN. KEITH KELLOGG, FORMER VP PENCE NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR: Worse. I don't remember exactly, that was something like that, yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Soon after the call ended, Trump would repeat his dangerous lies and put a target on Vice President Pence. I hope Mike is going to do the right thing. I hope so. And Mike Pence is going to have to come through for us.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: As that speech neared its end, inside the Capitol.MIKE PENCE, (R) FORMER U.S. VICE PRESIDENT: The Senate and House of Representatives are meeting a joint session to verify the certificates and count the votes of the electors.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But outside headed their way.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: There are thousands of people here already. This line wrapped around the Washington and the President is scheduled to speak.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: As Mr. Giuliani and I were walking through his vehicles that evening, he looked at me and said something to the effect of, Cas, are you excited for the sixth? We're going to the Capitol going to be great. President's going to be there. He's going to look powerful.

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: On January 3, the Capitol Police issued a special event assessment. Congress itself is the target on the sixth.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Now we're on, as they say the point of attack.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Listen to what Mr. Bannon said that day after the first call he had with the president.

utterances.speaker: STEVE BANNON, FORMER WHITE HOUSE CHIEF STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: All hell is going to break loose tomorrow. All I can say is strap in.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: And then he had Donald Trump talk again. And we don't know what the contents of those calls were because of course, Donald Trump has not provided that information. And Steve Bannon has not provided that information.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The night of January 5, you were among those summoned to the Oval Office.

utterances.speaker: SARAH MATTHEWS, FORMER WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY FOR TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Yes, so I was brought into the Oval Office that evening. And the entire press team was assembled in there.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The gates open just a few minutes ago.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: The president had the door to the Rose Garden open. And you could hear the crowd on the ellipse already assembled. And you could tell he was feeding off that energy and that he was really excited for the next day.

utterances.speaker: SHEALAH CRAIGHEAD, FORMER TRUMP WHITE HOUSE UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The president was making notes that talking about we should go to the Capitol, what's the best route to go to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The January 6 committee's presentation of testimony and documentation left no doubt that Trump had every intention of joining his supporters marched to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did the president tell you this that he wanted to speak at the Capitol?

utterances.speaker: NICK LUNA, FORMER ASSISTANT TO THE PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: Correct, yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We have the power in numbers. We came here to protect our republic.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The morning of January 6, supporters began gathering for the rally.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Biden did not win this election.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What do you think happened?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Fraud.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It's not made up.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Meanwhile the president's insistence on joining their march to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We're taking this country back.  [23

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Had White House lawyers such as Pat Cipollone, very worried. HUTCHINSON

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But nobody could change Trump's mind. And as he family and aides arrived at the rally, his Chief of Staff Mark Meadows was keeping the president's hopes alive.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: Prior to Mr. Trump taking the stage that morning, he was under the impression by Mr. Meadows that it was still possible.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: At the rally, the president had a more immediate familiar concern, crowd size.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: When we were in the off stage and that's very intent behind the stage. He was very concerned about the shot.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: For the pictures that were shared, he wanted to make sure that the rally space was full. And so, he's being told it's not that people are waiting to get through these mags, through these metal detectors. People don't want to go through them because they have weapons with them.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: During the hearings, the Select Committee showed a Secret Service report that, "some members of the crowd are wearing ballistic helmets, body armor and carrying radio equipment and military grade backpacks."

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: Let's listen.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The Committee also played police radio transmissions from that day. UNIDENTIFIED MALE

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I got three men walking down the street in fatigues carrying AR-15. Copy at 14th and Independence.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yet Trump wanted the metal detectors, the magnetometers or mags removed.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: When we were in the off-stage announce tent, I was in the vicinity of a conversation where I overheard the president say something to the effect of, you know, I don't effing care that they have weapons. They're not here to hurt me. Take the effing mags away. Let my people in. They can march to the Capitol from here. Let the people in, take the effing mags away.

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: Let's reflect on that for a moment. President Trump was aware that a number of the individuals in the crowd had weapons and were wearing body armor. And here's what President Trump instructed the crowd to do. TRUMP

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: How would you characterize Donald Trump's speech at the Ellipse on January 6?

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: Inciting. He said peacefully and patriotically that he was telling people go up there and it's hard not to see that that was fomenting and telling people that he had been harmed and they should be angry on his behalf.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You'll never take back our country with weakness. You have to show strength and you have to be strong.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Trump's national security advisors believe the President Codename, Mogul was going to join the procession.

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: MOGUL, the President was "going to the capitol" and "they're finding the best route now."

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The chat-log continues, military aid has confirmed that he wants to walk. They are begging him to reconsider. Current route will be 15th to F, F to 6th, 6th to Penn, Penn to the Capitol. So, this is happening.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There are millions of us here, don't let him lie to you.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What was he going to do up there?

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: I think just leave his people, leave his base, be with his base. I don't think this was something that he had thought out too well, other than he was acting like somebody who didn't think he had anything to lose.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: After more than an hour on stage, the president wrapped up his speech this way.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: When he got off the stage and everybody was making the movement back to the motorcade. I had overheard Mr. Meadows say to him, that he was still working on getting an off the record movement to the Capitol.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What happened next, as Trump and Secret Service agent Robert "Bobby" Engel got into the Presidential limousine known as the Beast, was relayed to Hutchinson by Trump's Deputy Chief of Staff, Tony Ornato. HUTCHINSONThe President had a very strong, very angry response to that. Tony described him as being irate. The president said something to the effect of, I'm the effing president. Take me up to the capitol now. To which Bobby responded, sir, we have to go back to the West Wing. President reached up towards the front of the vehicle to grab at the steering wheel. Mr. Engel grabbed his arm, said sir; you need to take your hand off the steering wheel. We're going back to the West Wing. We're not going to the Capitol. REP. ADAM KINZINGER, (R-IL): It's a shocking story. And we've now heard from at least a Washington D.C. detective, something very similar.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Trump would return to the White House and watch his supporters heed his call to fight like hell.(END VIDEOTAPE) (COMMERCIAL BREAK) (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The morning of January 6, what were your expectations for the day?

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: I think I woke up thinking that it was going to be a normal day. And I just thought that he was going to go out there and give a speech and that would be it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Sarah Matthews is Donald Trump's former Deputy White House Press Secretary and was in the White House on January 6.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: It was kind of quiet to be honest in the West Wing that morning at least.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That quiet would not last long. After the speeches at the Ellipse, the president returned to the White House and the rioters made their way to the capitol. Already aware of the increasing violence, Trump went into the private dining room just off the Oval Office at 1.25 p.m. and remain there until 4 p.m.

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: When Donald Trump is upset about what he is seeing, he reacts. He was not reacting here.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: For more than three hours, the President of the United States refused to call off the violent rioters who stormed the U.S. Capitol.

utterances.speaker: HABERMAN
utterances.sentences: He was watching television and admiring what he saw. You know, he was happy that the certification was delayed. There were myriad efforts to get him to issue some kind of a statement, those did not work. He didn't make a single phone call to any member of his government.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is now possibly a riot.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: At 1.49 pm.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: 1.49 hours declaring it a riot.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: When D.C. police officially declared this a riot, Trump tweeted out a link to his speech on the Ellipse. The very one that had helped incite that riot, realizing the severity of the situation, White House Counsel Pat Cipollone rushed to Mark Meadows, the President's Chief of Staff.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: And I remember Pat saying to him something to the effect of the rioters got to the capitol, Mark. We need to get on to the President now. And Mark looked up and said he doesn't want to do anything, Pat.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It's over. You better wrong cops.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Right as the violence surge, Trump tweeted; Mike Pence didn't have the courage to do what should have been done to protect our country and our constitution.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: It was the last thing that was really needed in that moment. It pretty much painted a target on the vice president's back by tweeting that out.

utterances.speaker: HUTCHINSON
utterances.sentences: I remember Pat saying something to the effect of, Mark, we need to do something more. They're literally calling for the Vice President to the effing hung. And Mark had responded something to the effect of, you heard him Pat, he thinks Mike deserves it.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: Working in communications for President Trump, I was very aware of just the impact that his words have on his supporters. That tweet suggested to them that what they were doing at the capitol was OK and that they were justified in their violence and that it was Vice President Pence who was allowing an election to be stolen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mike Pence has betrayed this president and he has betrayed the people of the United States.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Inside the capitol, the Vice President was rushed from The Senate Floor, Secret Service held Pence along with his family and aides in his Senate office as they work to clear a path to safety.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: If we lose any more time we may have, we may lose the ability to leave.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: A White House security official who chose to remain anonymous for fear of retaliation explained exactly how dire the situation was for Pence and his secret service detail.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: When the Secret Service made the call to move the vice president again, rioters came within 40 feet of him. As he was held in an undisclosed location, it was the vice president who directed a response to the riot.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It was Pence who was on the phone with these lawmakers Pence that was on the phone with people in the Pentagon about what was happening with the National Guard.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: At 2.38 pm, Trump tweeted, "Please support our capitol police and law enforcement they are truly on the side of our country, stay peaceful. By this point, rioters were in both chambers. And the Capitol Rotunda was filled with tear gas.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: At the end of the tweet, he used the phrase stay peaceful. Kayleigh McEnany shared with me that he did not want to include that and that it took a lot of convincing on their part that was extremely alarming to me.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The rioters were getting Trump's messages in real time as heard on walkie-talkie communications between rioters.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Trump just tweeted please support our capitol police they are on our side. Do not harm them.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He didn't say not to do anything to the Congressman.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I think what the committee's showed about Trump's tweets is that they do take them literally. His messages were received by the people who were there at the Capitol very loudly.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: At any moment during the siege on the capitol, the president could have addressed the country live from the White House.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: There's a camera on in the White House briefing room at all times. He could have walked over there, could have been on camera almost instantaneously and blasted out a message to the American people. He had every opportunity and he chose to not do that.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: When the president finally relented and released a video telling the rioters to go home, it was 4.17 p.m. Three hours and seven minutes since the riot began.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: It became very clear that the Feds basically had taken the capitol back over that they were not going to succeed in stopping the counting. And only then did he come out with that statement.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We had an election that was stolen from us. It was a landslide election and everyone knows it. MATTHEWS

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: So, go home. We love you. You're very special.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yet again, many rioters took the president's words as instructions.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I'm here delivering the president's message. Donald Trump has asked everybody to go home.

utterances.speaker: MATTHEWS
utterances.sentences: Working in communications for him, I knew that I would be tasked with defending that. And we had just witnessed all this violence at the capitol and these folks attacking police officers, chanting horrible things. And I knew that I couldn't defend that because it was indefensible. I resigned that evening. TAPPER

utterances.speaker: RUDY GIULIANI, FORMER ATTORNEY TO DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'm calling you because I want to discuss with you how they're trying to rush this hearing. TAPPER

utterances.speaker: HERSCHMANN
utterances.sentences: I said to him, are you out of your effing mind? Now, I'm going to give you the best free legal advice you're ever getting in your life. Get a great effing criminal defense lawyer. You're going to need it. And then I hung up on him.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And the president released a second video condemning the violence more forcefully on January 7.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Like all Americans I am outraged by the violence, lawlessness and mayhem.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But according to White House Aide, Cassidy Hutchinson, it was only the threat of his cabinet invoking the 25th Amendment that convinced him to make this video. Advisors warned Trump that talk of removing him from office was gaining traction.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And even then, he still refused to admit the election was over.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: This election is now over. Congress has certified the results. I don't want to say the election is over. I just want to say congress has certified the results without saying the election is over, OK. TAPPER

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: I want the American people to look at these hearings who understand how close we came that day to losing that self-governance.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: He was trying to basically change out the DOJ to be people sympathetic to him to give at least the air of federal complicity in challenging election results. And he knew when he was sitting in the office during the attack on January 6, that there was a chance that would succeed.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: What do you want Americans to take away from the hearings that you've held so far?

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: I want the American people to look at these hearings and understand how close we came that day to losing that self-governance. Freedom isn't free. You have to defend this and not just overseas but sometimes here at home.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Do you miss me yet? Do you miss me?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: In the aftermath of January 6 and his election loss.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Anthony Gonzalez, that's another beauty.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump has made it his mission to root out everyone in the Republican Party that has opposed him.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: --John Katko, David Valadao.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Of the 10 Republicans in the House of Representatives who voted to impeach him, only two remain.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Get rid of a wall. TAPPER

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: Our obligation, my obligation very much is above politics. I can't imagine having done anything differently at any stage of this process since January 6. It saddens me that so many of my Republican colleagues have not met the moment.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Kinzinger and Cheney are the only two Republicans on the House Select Committee to investigate the attack on January 6. They have become pariahs in a party, where they were once seen as its future.

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: We cannot survive as a party existing on the personality of one man. TAPPER

utterances.speaker: KINZINGER
utterances.sentences: This baton is passed from us to the Department of Justice to say are you going to defend the constitution? And if there is laws that have been broken, and I certainly think there have been.

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: I think clearly what we've laid out indicates that the former President of the United States was involved in efforts that we're not only unconstitutional, but also violated the law.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The committee has indicated it believes Donald Trump potentially committed obstruction of an official proceeding of congress and conspiracy to defraud the United States, amongst other potential crimes. The conspiracy charge may be particularly difficult to prove.

utterances.speaker: DONOGHUE
utterances.sentences: You have to have criminal intent. Here, you have the problem of proving what was in the president's mind. I've heard people say, well, he was willfully blind. Should he have known? Yes. But if he did not, I don't know that that's a crime.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Not everyone shares that view.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: Willful ignorance of fact or law by the President of the United States would not be either a legal defense or a political defense to the president. That's about as clear as a former judge could say it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Ultimately, the Department of Justice will decide whether to bring any charges and who will be charged. In September, the Justice Department issued another sweeping set of subpoenas to more than 30 people in the former president's orbit. And there are multiple federal grand juries handling the investigation.

utterances.speaker: MURRAY
utterances.sentences: We know the Justice Department has been investigating Jeffrey Clark. We also know that John Eastman is someone who has been touched by this investigation.

utterances.speaker: EASTMAN
utterances.sentences: I'd like to see the warrant before you take my property.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Both Jeffrey Clark and John Eastman have had their phones seized by federal investigators. Clark dismissed the investigation as politically motivated and Eastman fought the DOJ search warrant in court. But there are state level investigations as well. Rudy Giuliani has been informed he's a target and a Georgia investigation.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.sentences: We will not talk about this until it's over.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And appeared before a grand jury in August. At the moment perhaps the most perilous investigation for Donald Trump has nothing to do with the attack on the capitol.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Former President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago home in Florida, has been searched by the FBI.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The government has recovered more than 320 classified documents from Trump's home in Florida. The redacted search warrant identified three federal crimes at the Department of Justice lists as the foundation of its investigation, obstruction of justice, criminal handling of government records, and violations of the Espionage Act.REP. BENNIE THOMPSON, (D-MI): Good afternoon.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The Committee is laser focused on their own investigations. After the hearings this summer they continued digging, even securing an interview with Ginni Thomas, a conservative activist and wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, where according to Committee Chair Bennie Thompson, she doubled down on her false belief that the election was stolen.Text messages between Thomas and Mark Meadows showed she pushed the former chief of staff to fight to overturn the results of the election before January 6. And at its last hearing in October, the Committee voted to subpoena all relevant documents and testimony from former President Trump.

utterances.speaker: THOMPSON
utterances.sentences: Those in favor will say hi, those opposed, no. In the opinion of the Chair, the eyes have it.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Since that vote Vice Chair Liz Cheney has said publicly that the committee is in talks for potential testimony from Trump. How much these hearings have impacted the country's view of Trump remains unclear.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I think the January 6 hearings actually presented a pretty concise case. And I do think that it got through to voters and I think it was partly because it was Trump's own appointees, Republican appointees, who were the ones they used to testify against him, whether that lingers in voters' minds, I think is a real open question.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I don't think that they've wanted him in a sense of; they've changed a lot of minds. His supporters either don't care or still believe what he says, which is that the election was stolen and that Biden is not legitimately elected president.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Of the 10 Republicans who voted to impeach Donald Trump based on the January 6 attack on the Capitol, eight of them are either retiring or have been defeated in primaries. What does that say to you?

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: That Donald Trump and his supporters are a clear and present danger to American democracy.

utterances.speaker: ALYSSA FARAH GRIFFIN, FORMER WHITE HOUSE COMMUNICATIONS DIRECTOR FOR TRUMP
utterances.sentences: He's already moving mountains and putting things in motion to be able to oppose a future election result that doesn't go his way, whether it's promoting conspiracy theorists and advocating for them and campaigning for them as secretaries of state, or backing governors of key swing states who are going to support his election lies.He's putting all these things in motion and we should be watching it and knowing that it's for future plans that he has.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: A lot of the people we've interviewed have expressed concerns not just about what happened, but what will happen. In fact, we see a whole bunch of election liars running for office. Are you worried?

utterances.speaker: CHENEY
utterances.sentences: I'm very worried. The responsibility that we all have to make sure that we defend our republic and that we defend our institutions has to be above politics, there are people running so that they are in a position that they will be able to certify the results only for Donald Trump. That's obviously fundamentally a threat to the survival of the Republic. And I think those people have all got to be defeated.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You've been shouting from the rooftops. This is not just about 2020, you're worried about 2024. You're worried about future elections.

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: I am and right now the former president and his allies and supporters, including in congress and including in the states represented clear and present danger to American democracy. That's not because of what they did on January 6, is because of what they pledged to do in 2024.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Do you think that Republicans are hearing what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: LUTTIG
utterances.sentences: I hope they are. There's no evidence that they've heard anything to date.
